list_definition.definition: to (cause to) go down below the surface of water etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The torpedo sank the battleship immediately
The ship sank in deep water.

list_definition.definition: to go down or become lower (slowly)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The sun sank slowly behind the hills
Her voice sank to a whisper.
The ink sank into the paper
He sank his teeth into an apple.

list_definition.definition: (of one’s spirits etc) to become depressed or less hopeful

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: My heart sinks when I think of the difficulties ahead.
He sank all his savings in the business.

list_definition.mean_english: bồn rửa bát, chậu rửa bát
list_definition.definition: a kind of basin with a drain and a water supply connected to it

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He washed the dishes in the sink.

list_ex_of_english: A consequence of water current is that dispersal between pairs of sinks occurs downstream.
A projection is applied whenever an inward directed wave-front occurs as the immediate super-term of a sink term.
The small cemented courtyard was sunk into the ground as a basin to avoid rainwater penetrating the inner chamber.
In these localities, eggs which sink to the bottom are likely to survive for successful transmission to potential intermediate hosts, such as benthic copepods.
Stationary nongyrotropy may be maintained by sources and sinks in velocity space.
As a most basic example, a single, qualitative trait (sinking versus floating in water) was assessed.
Stationary nongyrotropies are maintained in an open velocity space by sources and sinks, whereas rotating ones are normally source- and loss-free.
This inclusion is in fact simple because the source/sink terms enter with opposite signs in the equations for ions and neutrals.
